results.title: Day to Day Care of Your Horse
results.brief_description: Captain Mark Phillips makes the young and fairly inexperienced horse person aware of the basic everyday care required to keep one’s horse in top condition. These requirements include: good stabling; field and fencing requirements; a daily routine of grooming etc.; exercise; and general information about veterinary care.

results.title: Day at night: I.M. Pei
results.brief_description: Interview with leading U.S. architect and designer, I.M. Pei. Covers his views on the Beaux Arts system under which he trained, his reasons for feeling that an elitist and exclusive view of architecture is no longer valid. He stresses the importance of urban housing in turning cities from places of commerce to areas offering their inhabitants a genuine richness of life

results.title: Dawn of the solar age
results.brief_description: SUMMARY: A survey of current methods of, and projects for, harnessing solar energy is presented in an attempt to answer the question - when oil supplies end, can the world’s industries be run by solar energy?

results.title: Davy Jones' locker
results.brief_description: From the animated series “Willie Whopper’s Adventures”, the story of Willie Whopper, a little boy with a big imagination. Willie tangles with denizens of the deep, including a vast and menacing Poseidon figure and a drunken pirate (Davy Jones), who swills hooch while slamming his peg-leg stump on the deck of his room. Lots of sea-creature sight gags, too.

results.title: David Kennedy [ALP Member for Bendigo]
results.brief_description: Campaign film for ALP Member for Bendigo, David Kennedy. Features footage of Kennedy campaigning in the streets of Bendigo with Gough Whitlam and being interviewed about his views on Bendigo and his family. Issues of concern to the community are raised such as postal services, state of the education system, and loss of youth to the bigger cities. Also desire for a National Health Scheme and concern for wheat farmers. Features good shots of historical interest of Bendigo in the early 1970s. Script by Bill Hartley.

results.title: David
results.creator_credit: Paul Dickson, James Carr, BFI and World Wide Pictures
results.brief_description: Illustrates the harsh reality of life in a coal mining town using documentary and fictional techniques. Made in Ammanford, Wales, the film recounts the life of Daffyd Rhys employed as a caretaker for the local school following a coal mine explosion. The story is related by one of the school’s former pupils and covers Daffyd’s early life in the coal mines, his courtship and marriage, his work as a poet, the death of his son, and his life at the school. Most of the roles are performed by the people of Ammanford resulting in a realistic portrayal of life in the Welsh coal mining community. The film was presented as Wales contribution to the Festival of Britain.

results.title: Daumier
results.creator_credit: Nico Crama and Mary Van Den Heyer
results.brief_description: Daumier was a ninteenth century eyewitness of England and Europe: the observer of great and small men. This film shows some of his lighographic cartoons and caricatures which relate to the period 1830-1873.

results.title: Das Rheingold
results.creator_credit: Brian Large, Otto Schenk, Channel 4, Deutsche Grammophon, La Sept, Metropolitan Opera (New York, N.Y.) and Osterreichischer Rundfunk-Fernsehen
results.brief_description: In the first opera in Richard Wagner’s massive Ring Cycle, the Rhinegold is stolen by Alberich from the Rhine maidens and later fashioned into a ring of power, thus setting in train the saga which culminates in Die Gotterdammerung. The Metropolitan Opera Orchestra and Chorus is conducted by James Levine and the cast includes Christa Ludwig, Ekkehard Wlaschina, and James Morris. Sung in German, the video is accompanied by a synopsis. Wagner’s Ring Cycle consists of four parts, in this order: Das Rheingold; Die Walkuere; Siegfried and Goetterdaemmerung.

results.title: Darwin and the theory of natural selection
results.brief_description: Young Charles Darwin’s voyage on HMS Beagle resulted in discoveries that have had a profound effect on nearly every field of human knowlledge. Through Darwin’s observations off the coasts and islands of South America and experiments made in England, we see how this scientist developed his Theory of Natural Selection. Many rare views of animals and plant life were photographed on the Galapagos Islands.
